Oakmont versus Prodigy and in that case the Court held that because Prodigy
exercised editorial control over their bulletin board system they were like an
editor and were responsible as a publisher for any defamatory statements that were contained on that system this

their trying they incurred liability for the statements that everybody on the system made another case was cubby
versus CompuServe in that case the court basically said that there was liability for defamatory statements only if
CompuServe knew or should have known that the defamatory comments were on
their system and what happened was the United States Congress and the lobbyists of AOL and other big isps took a look at

with the obscenity thing but some of the provisions still apply and one of them is 47 USC two thirds section 230c this
is the Good Samaritan provision there's no civil liability on the
account of any action taken voluntarily or in good faith to restrict access to or availability of online
material that the user or provider considers to be objectionable so if I'm going to be like Prodigy and make it a
family-oriented thing I'm not going to incur liability for trying to you know exercise an editorial control it also
completely immunizes an ISP for defamatory statements that are placed on
